image.altText: An image of a small carpark next to a Middle Arm boat ramp.

items.synopsis: NT government documents show so-called blue hydrogen requiring natural gas will play a significant role at the Middle Arm Sustainable Development Precinct on Darwin Harbour.

title.children: Documents show natural gas could play major role in $1.5b Middle Arm precinct

image.altText: Wells smiles as she holds an elderly womans hand and listens to her speak.

items.synopsis: The aged care minister leaves the door open for wealthy people to fund their own aged care, or imposing a levy on Australians to pay for rising costs, as baby boomers begin to enter the system.

title.children: 'The boomers are coming': Aged care minister leaves door open for levy for ageing Australia

image.altText: A female Aedes aegypti mosquito bites someone's skin.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory has recorded seven cases and two deaths from Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE) this year, as the health department urges people to protect themselves against mosquito bites.

title.children: Outbreak of mosquito-borne disease in the NT sparks health warning

image.altText: Peter Dutton wearing black glasses standing in front of a blurry australian flag looking straight toward the camera

items.synopsis: Peter Dutton denies members of his party deliberately misrepresented the opinions of federal court judges during debate on the constitution alteration bill on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Dutton denies shadow ministers misrepresented federal court judges during Voice debate

image.altText: Pedestrians

items.synopsis: Australia's economy grew by 0.2 per cent in the March quarter, slower than economists were expecting, dragging the annual rate down to just 2.3 per cent.

title.children: 'Lowest household saving in 15 years': Australia’s economy grows by 'slower than expected' 0.2pc in March quarter

items.synopsis: The government will pay refunds to opal miners who have been stripped of their licences due to an administrative error.

title.children: Miners to receive compensation after department's eight-year blunder leaves them without jobs

image.altText: a female doctor assisting a baby in a crib

items.synopsis: Forty-five medical specialists, supported by federal independent MP Monique Ryan, have outlined their concerns of both the direct and indirect health risks of fracking in a letter addressed to the NT Chief Minister.

title.children: Paediatricians sound alarm over fracking-related health risks

image.altText: A saltwater crocodile lies in a billabong in Kakadu National Park.

items.synopsis: The opening of some of Kakadu National Park's premier waterfalls and swimming holes has been delayed weeks into peak season because crocodile surveys have not yet been completed, to the dismay of NT tourism operators.

title.children: Tourism operators dismayed as key Kakadu sites kept closed by crocodiles

image.altText: Police looking at a break in through a dark window

items.synopsis: Katherine, Darwin, Groote Eylandt and Lajamanu in the NT are among 15 communities across the country which will get a share of $81.5 million in federal funding to develop justice reinvestment strategies.

title.children: 'Local solutions to local problems': NT communities welcome justice reinvestment support

image.altText: Man walks on street

items.synopsis: The former NSW Labor minister and convicted paedophile is being treated for multiple injuries after the incident on Tuesday afternoon.

title.children: Disgraced MP Milton Orkopoulos bashed in prison, treated for multiple injuries

image.altText: A young Asian woman with long dark hair poses for a selfie.

items.synopsis: The mother of slain Melbourne woman Ju Zhang comes face-to-face with her daughter's killer in the Supreme Court, calling for the harshest of punishments to be handed down.

title.children: Tip worker who found Melbourne woman's body tells court he 'cannot believe' cruelty of her murder

image.altText: Pope Francis raises his hand and holds a white book in front of him

items.synopsis: Pope Francis will be put under general anaesthesia and hospitalised for several days following abdominal surgery in Rome.

title.children: Pope Francis to undergo abdominal surgery, stay in hospital for several days

image.altText: Pat Cummins holds a helmet

items.synopsis: Australia and India, the two top-ranked Test sides in the world, lock horns at The Oval to decide who will be the second ICC World Test Champions. Follow all the day one action in our live blog.

title.children: India win toss, bat first against Australia in World Test Championship Final

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And here's how Australia will line up. DA Warner, UT Khawaja, M Labuschagne, SPD Smith, TM Head, C Green, AT Carey (wicketkeeper), MA Starc, PJ Cummins (captain), NM Lyon, SM Boland .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia team

children.content: And here's how Australia will line up.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: So here is the India team. RG Sharma (captain), Shubman Gill, CA Pujara, V Kohli, AM Rahane, KS Bharat (wicketkeeper), RA Jadeja, SN Thakur, UT Yadav, Mohammed Shami, Mohammed Siraj.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: India team

children.content: So here is the India team.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: On a very, green pitch. Think Gabba last year green. A great result for India, you'd think. And judging by the amount of noise that greeted that announcement, the majority of the crowd arte pretty pumped too. Four seamers and a spinner for India, but that spinner is NOT Ravichandran Ashwin, the number one ranked bowler in Test cricket. Ravindra Jadeja is the tweaker who gets the nod. "We would have had a bowl as well but I don't think it's going to make too much of a difference," says Captain Pat. Scott Boland will play for Australia and I, for one, am excited to see how he goes in England with a Duke ball. He may be getting a new nickname of Mark Knopfler if he performs as I expect him too...
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: India wins the toss, will bowl

children.content: On a very, green pitch. Think Gabba last year green.
A great result for India, you'd think.
And judging by the amount of noise that greeted that announcement, the majority of the crowd arte pretty pumped too.
Four seamers and a spinner for India, but that spinner is NOT Ravichandran Ashwin, the number one ranked bowler in Test cricket. Ravindra Jadeja is the tweaker who gets the nod.
"We would have had a bowl as well but I don't think it's going to make too much of a difference," says Captain Pat.
Scott Boland will play for Australia and I, for one, am excited to see how he goes in England with a Duke ball.
He may be getting a new nickname of Mark Knopfler if he performs as I expect him too...

image.altText: A blue sign with white writing on a building that reads "Jenny Craig".

items.synopsis: Jenny Craig's Australian and New Zealand operations will immediately stop trading after administrators failed to find a buyer for the weight-loss company's physical stores.

title.children: Jenny Craig collapses in Australia and New Zealand after no buyer found for weight-loss company

image.altText: A satellite image shows Nova Kakhovka Dam in Kherson.

items.synopsis: On the morning the Nova Kakhokva dam was blown up in southern Ukraine, resident Hanna Zarudnia woke to both shelling and flooding. Then she was "surrounded by water from all sides".

title.children: 'The volume of water is colossal': The moment a Ukrainian dam was destroyed and the war changed forever

image.altText: A woman carries a dog and a plastic bag as she walks through knee-high water along a flooded street.

items.synopsis: The US says it is "not certain" where the blame for the dam's destruction lies, but it does not make sense that Kyiv would unleash an environmental disaster on its own people.

title.children: Dam destruction leaves at least seven missing as state of emergency imposed in Russia-controlled parts of Kherson

image.altText: A large yacht at sea

items.synopsis: A 53.5m luxury superyacht was sold earlier this year to pay back debts to international creditors, but more than $4 million owed to customers is unlikely to be returned.

title.children: Customers are $4 million out of pocket after cruise company collapses

image.altText: Two woman stand next to a sign, one with their hands in the air

items.synopsis: Like Ayers Rock became Uluru, from today Queensland's Fraser Island will officially be known by its Indigenous name, which means paradise.

title.children: 'Long time coming': Queensland's iconic Fraser Island officially named K'gari

image.altText: A close up of someone writing on a blank cheque

items.synopsis: Australia is set to be a cheque-less society by 2030, if the federal government has its way. The treasurer says it's a costly way of dealing with "a tiny and declining fraction of payments".

title.children: Cheques will be phased out by 2030 as the use of mobile wallets sky-rockets

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a grey polo shirt and dark cap swings a golf club.

items.synopsis: "Two years of disruption and distraction" in golf are over and pending lawsuits between the parties will now be dropped — and missing from all the announcements was Australia's Greg Norman, the commissioner of LIV Golf.

title.children: 'People will call me a hypocrite': Why golf competitions the PGA, LIV and European Tour are merging

image.altText: A woman in sixties style dress stands in front of four framed paintings on a wall

items.synopsis: Acclaimed French artist, author and former partner of Pablo Picasso, Françoise Gilot, dies age 101.

title.children: Françoise Gilot, who had two children with Pablo Picasso before dumping him, dies aged 101

image.altText: Couple face away from the camera and look at a phone in the middle of them.

items.synopsis: Needle spiking is when a person is injected with a drug without their consent, and it's unknown how much it's happening in Australian venues.

title.children: Two friends blacked out while at a bar. Then they found the needle prick

image.altText: Before 1850s designed shop-fronts, horses pull a carriage in which a small group of people sit.

items.synopsis: Operations at Sovereign Hill could be affected if workers decide to go on a full strike.

title.children: Workers at one of Victoria's most loved tourist attractions threaten to strike

image.altText: Two Bitcoins held in both hands with a Binance price chart opened in the background.

items.synopsis: The cryptocurrency industry has long argued tokens do not constitute a "security", however the results of cases against Binance and Coinbase could change that.

title.children: Crypto crackdown by US securities could transform the industry

image.altText: Lightning across a dark sky on a beach with a jetty

items.synopsis: In a complete reverse of the cold pattern of southerly winds in May, we are now seeing one of the warmest starts to winter on record.

title.children: Unseasonable storms bring warmest start to Australian winter in decades

image.altText: Water bottles and garbage float on the surface of water

items.synopsis: A marine waste collection company says there has been a significant reduction in plastic bags recovered from the harbour. But one big issue still needs to be addressed.

title.children: 'Staggering' fall in plastic bags polluting Sydney Harbour — but there's still much to do

image.altText: Anonymous woman's hands rolling a cannabis joint.

items.synopsis: CSIRO staff across the nation would be randomly tested for the presence of drugs in their system under a plan from management. That would include testing for cannabis, even though a large number of staff are legally able to possess and use the drug.

title.children: CSIRO planning to introduce random drug testing of workers
